metadata.case_name: Northern Railway Co-operative Credit Society Ltd., Jodhpur v. Kanraj Mehta & Ors.

facts.text: The appellant is the Northern Railway Co-operative Credit Society Ltd., Jodhpur, registered in 1920 under the Co-operative Societies Act, employing 10 or 11 persons including Kanraj Mehta (Head Clerk), Madho Lal (Accountant), and clerks A.C. Sharma, V.D. Sharma, G.S. Saxena.
At Committee of Management meeting on 6th April 1956, decided to hold 36th and 37th Annual General Meetings for 1953-54 and 1954-55 on 28th April 1956.
Kanraj Mehta applied for leave on medical grounds on 8th April 1956 with certificate from registered Vaid, initially 4 days, extended up to 2nd May 1956.
Other four clerks (A.C. Sharma, V.D. Sharma, G.S. Saxena) applied for leave between 12th-15th April 1956 on similar medical certificates, continued up to 30th April-4th May 1956.
Society's case: These employees conspired to paralyse Society's working ahead of AGM on 28th April 1956 by collectively submitting sickness certificates.

Society issued letter to Kanraj directing him to attend Railway Dispensary for medical examination by Dr. I.B.P. Mathur on 20th April 1956 at 7.45 hrs; Kanraj did not comply, continued sending leave applications with Vaid certificates.
Leave applications of Kanraj never sanctioned but allowed to resume duty on 3rd May 1956.

Charge-sheet issued to Kanraj on 19th May 1956 containing five charges: (1) instigate/conspire to paralyse by collective sick certificates; (2) disobedience in not attending medical exam; (3) active part in leaflets against management; (4) vilifying propaganda re elections; (5) instigating depositors to withdraw deposits.
Kanraj replied to charge-sheet on 25th May 1956: charges vague, no specific offences under rules, denied charges, requested Railway/Union official or shareholder to represent him at enquiry.
Enquiry Committee appointed: Shri Deodutta Gaur (Chairman), Bhailal, Vishvadeo Purohit; informed to Kanraj on 28th June 1956, allowed co-employee but not outsider.
Kanraj insisted on Railway employee/Union official representation, refused to participate without it.

Committee submitted report on 4th August 1956: proceeded on record without Kanraj, charges proved; later clarified examined evidence independently, 3-4 witnesses verbally corroborating charges 1,3,4,5.
Vice-Chairman issued show cause notice on 5th September 1956: provisional decision to dismiss, show cause within 7 days.
Kanraj on 13th September 1956 requested full copy of enquiry proceedings/findings.
Society replied same day: 3 days grace as matter of grace, no enquiry report envisaged, dilatory replies not accepted.
Kanraj replied 16th September 1956: grievance no representation, no guilt, charges vague, explanations per charge.
Removal order issued 17th September 1956 effective that day; minor punishments to other three clerks.

Dispute raised by Uttariya Railway Mazdoor Union, Jodhpur; Government of Rajasthan referred to Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan, Jaipur under s.10(1)(d) Industrial Disputes Act: whether removal of Kanraj and stopping increments of others illegal/unjustified, relief?

Tribunal award dated 7th October 1963: Kanraj's demand for stranger representation unjustified; but entitled to copies of Committee reports for second show cause; charges vague; set aside removal, restored to position on 13th Sept 1956, Society may reinstitute enquiry.

Society filed Art.226 petition in Rajasthan High Court for prohibition: reference not industrial dispute as not sponsored by Society workmen; dismissed 7th Feb 1962, sponsored by 4/11 workmen; no appeal.
Post-Tribunal: Kanraj reinstated, fresh proceedings against him, fresh removal order, another dispute pending on compensation.

legal_issues.text: Whether the reference to Industrial Tribunal was competent as an industrial dispute, given sponsorship by Railway Union not Society workmen.
Whether the domestic enquiry was valid, particularly regarding Kanraj's right to representation by outsider, vagueness of charges, and opportunity to defend.
Whether principles of natural justice required supply of enquiry reports/documents before second show cause notice, and validity of removal order.
Whether reinstatement justified despite Society's loss of confidence in Kanraj.

petitioner_arguments.text: Reference incompetent: individual dispute of four employees, not industrial dispute as not taken up by Society workmen; Railway Union irrelevant.

Tribunal held Kanraj not entitled to stranger representation, enquiry valid; limit to post-13th Sept 1956; no need for second show cause or documents as no Art.311, mere indulgence; charges not vague.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principles of natural justice do not require second show cause

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if removal unjustified, no reinstatement due to loss of confidence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Assam Oil Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court order interlocutory, challengeable in appeal against Tribunal award; not res judicata.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Satyadhyan Ghosal v. Sm. Deorajin Debi

respondent_arguments.text: High Court dismissal of Art.226 petition final, res judicata bars re-agitating reference competency.
Support Tribunal on other grounds: charges vague, no details to defend; no rules requiring medical exam obedience; material not disclosed; entitled to enquiry reports for second show cause.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Principles of natural justice; can support on grounds negatived by Tribunal (Rambhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar; Powari Tea Estate v. Barkataki)

court_reasoning.text: Reference competency plea barred by res judicata: High Court Art.226 judgment final, independent proceeding, not interlocutory; appellant failed to appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.226 proceedings terminate finally; Ramesh v. Gendalal distinguishes from interlocutory orders.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents can support Tribunal on grounds negatived or patent on record, even without cross-appeal.

Charges vague, no details (except charge 2, but no rules mandating exam by specific doctor; Vaid certificate valid); justified plea unable to reply; material not disclosed; no adequate opportunity pre-enquiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Kanraj unreasonable on representation, but does not validate enquiry.

court_reasoning.text: Second show cause only opportunity satisfying natural justice due to prior defects; Tribunal justified in setting aside removal, allowing fresh enquiry with documents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No Art.311, but natural justice required.

court_reasoning.text: Reinstatement direction not interfered with given subsequent reinstatement, fresh removal, pending dispute on compensation.

holdings.text: High Court Art.226 judgment final and binding; reference competency not re-agitable.
Domestic enquiry invalid due to vague charges and non-disclosure of material; natural justice required opportunity via second show cause with documents.
Removal order set aside justified; Society may hold fresh enquiry.
Tribunal's reinstatement upheld given subsequent events.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satyadhyan Ghosal v. Sm. Deorajin Debi
precedents_cited.relevance: Interlocutory orders in pending suits not res judicata if not appealed; inapplicable to final Art.226 writ.
Art.226 proceedings independent and final, not continuation like appeal/revision.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rambhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji
precedents_cited.relevance: Respondent can support decree on grounds negatived by lower court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Powari Tea Estate v. Barkataki M.K.
precedents_cited.relevance: Judgment upheld on ground patent on record though not considered by Labour Court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Assam Oil Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Loss of confidence may bar reinstatement, but inapplicable due to subsequent events.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for government reference to Tribunal.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.226 petition; Art.311 principles analogous but not applicable; appeals.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Tribunal's award upheld setting aside Kanraj's removal due to vague charges and violation of natural justice; restored to 13th Sept 1956 position; Society at liberty to reinstitute enquiry; no interference with reinstatement given subsequent proceedings.
outcome.relief_granted: Kanraj restored to position as on 13-09-1956; liberty for fresh enquiry.

key_quotes.text: "The charges, as we have indicated above, which were served on Kanraj were very vague and he had no opportunity to give a reply to them."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "This subsequent show cause notice by the Vice-Chairman was, no doubt, not required by any rule or law analogous to Art. 311 of the Constitution, but ... the only opportunity which could have satisfied the requirement of principles of natural justice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains upholding Tribunal despite no legal mandate for second notice.

key_quotes.text: "Kanraj was taking a very unreasonable and undesirable attitude ... refusing to participate in the enquiry deserves to be condemned. That circumstance however, will not make the enquiry valid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Acknowledges employee's fault but prioritizes procedural fairness.
